conclusion: Determine how far the point light source S must be moved vertically upward so that the light emitted from S is just not visible above the water surface.
Involves understanding the geometry of the situation and applying Snell's Law.
The circular wooden board has a radius r and is stationary on the surface of the liquid. The point light source S is located directly below the center O of the board at a depth of H = sqrt(3)r.
Snell's Law states: n1 sin(theta1) = n2 sin(theta2), where n1 and n2 are the refractive indices of the two media, and theta1 and theta2 are the angles of incidence and refraction respectively.
In our case: n1 = 1 (air), n2 = sqrt(2) (liquid).
Find the critical angle theta_c where total internal reflection occurs using sin(theta_c) = n1/n2 = 1/sqrt(2) = sqrt(2)/2.
When the light source is moved vertically upward by a distance h, the new depth of the light source below the surface of the liquid will be H - h.
For the light to be just not visible above the surface, the angle of incidence in the liquid must be exactly 45 degrees.

Using the right triangle formed by the depth of the light source, the horizontal distance from the center of the board to the point where the light exits the liquid, and the line of sight, tan(45 degrees) = d/(H - h).
Since tan(45 degrees) = 1, 1 = d/(H - h), so d = H - h.
From the geometry of the circle, the horizontal distance d is also equal to r, so r = H - h.
Solve for h: h = H - r.
Substitute H = sqrt(3)r into the equation: h = sqrt(3)r - r.
The point source S should be moved vertically upward by a distance of (sqrt(3) - 1)r.
